com.mapmyfitness.android.mmfremoteappexample.app.com.mapmyfitness.android.mmfremote
Class RemoteManager

java.lang.Object
  com.mapmyfitness.android.mmfremoteappexample.app.com.mapmyfitness.android.mmfremote.RemoteManager

public class RemoteManager
extends java.lang.Object

This is the main entry point for the SDK. An instance of this class will be built using RemoteManager.Builder. You can use this SDK to maintain multiple connections to multiple apps, or multiple connections to one app. You can use one instance of this class for each of those connections. This SDK uses your app's android.content.Context to bind to an exposed android.app.Service in the MMF apps. Each of our apps has a unique IntentFilter action name to trigger the connection. The filters are held in the AppPackage enum. Distributed with these docs should be a sample client app that shows how to use this SDK to connect to our apps. To build it: 

     RemoteManager.Builder remoteControlBuilder = RemoteManager.getBuilder();
          remoteControlBuilder.setContext(this);
          remoteControlBuilder.setStatsCache(mMmfStatsCache);
          remoteControlBuilder.setDataListener(this);
          remoteControlBuilder.setCommandListener(this);
          remoteControlBuilder.setAppPackage(AppPackage.MAPMYRUN);

          try {
              mMmfRemoteManager = remoteControlBuilder.build();
          } catch (RemoteException e) {
              Log.e(TAG, e.getMessage(), e);
          }
After building the object you can use it connect it to an MMF app, or get the state if the app is already connected: 
     if (!mMmfRemoteManager.isAppConnected()) {
              updateUi(AppState.APP_NOT_CONNECTED);
              connectApp();
          } else {
              mMmfRemoteManager.requestAppState();
          }
You can also send commands like this: 
     try {
              mMmfRemoteManager.startWorkoutCommand();
          } catch (RemoteException e) {
              if (e.getCode() == RemoteException.Code.APP_NOT_CONNECTED) {
                  // Do something on the UI
                  connectApp();
              }
          }

Method Detail

getVersionNumber

public int getVersionNumber()
get the version number of this SDK. It will be versioned accordingly: - First 3 digits are patches - Fourth and fifth digits are minor - Sixth and seventh digits are major releases. Thus, a version might look like 1010300. That would be equivalent to 1.1.3.

Returns:
version number of the SDK

tryToConnectToMmfApp

public boolean tryToConnectToMmfApp(AppPackage appPackage)
Try to connect to the MMF app by passing it an AppPackage This method will set the package and call tryToConnectToMmfApp()

Returns:
true if it is already connected or the connection was successful, false if connection failed

tryToConnectToMmfApp

public boolean tryToConnectToMmfApp()
Try to connect to the MMF app in the currently assigned AppPackage. If this enum is null, this method will simply return false. You can use tryToConnectToMmfApp(AppPackage) if you would like to pass it one at the time you try to connect, or use getAppPackage() to check if one is present.

Returns:

app package

Set the AppPackage you would like to use to connect to an MMF app.

Parameters:

setStatsCache

public void setStatsCache(StatsCache statsCache)
Set a StatsCache to use during the session. This can be null and no data will be cached automatically. You can also set it during the building of this class.

Parameters:
statsCache - set a cache

return the cache

setDataListener

public void setDataListener(RemoteDataListener remoteDataListener)
Set the RemoteDataListener to receive callbacks for data changes during the lifetime of a workout. This can be set to null, in which case you will not be notified when the changes happen.

Parameters:
remoteDataListener - the listener to receive the data callbacks

setCommandListener

public void setCommandListener(RemoteCommandListener remoteCommandListener)
Set the RemoteCommandListener to receive callbacks for commands from the phone. Whenever you send a command to the MMF app, it will take the appropriate action and send the command back. That is how you can be sure that the MMF app responded property. For example, if you use the saveWorkoutCommand() it will send it to th phone. The MMF app on the phone will try to start, it it is successful it will send a callback to onStartWorkoutEvent(Boolean metric, Boolean hasHeartRate, Boolean calculatesCalories, Boolean isSpeed); This can be null, but then you won't be notified of events from the phone.

Parameters:
remoteCommandListener - the listener to receive the data callbacks

disconnectFromMmfApp

public void disconnectFromMmfApp()
Disconnect from the current MMF app. If the app is not currently connected this method does nothing. You can check if the app is connected by calling isAppConnected();

startWorkoutCommand

public void startWorkoutCommand()
                         throws RemoteException
Tell the MMF app to start a workout. This method will check if the app is connected. If it is not it will throw a RemoteException with RemoteException.Code.APP_NOT_CONNECTED

Throws:
RemoteException - if app is not connected.

discardWorkoutCommand

public void discardWorkoutCommand()
                           throws RemoteException
Tell the MMF app to discard a workout. This will erase all data from the workout that was recorded permanently. If user triggers this method you may want to have him confirm his action. This method will check if the app is connected. If it is not it will throw a RemoteException with RemoteException.Code.APP_NOT_CONNECTED

Throws:
RemoteException - if app is not connected.

saveWorkoutCommand

public void saveWorkoutCommand()
                        throws RemoteException
Tell the MMF app to save a workout. Saving means this workout will be saved to our servers under the account the user is logged in the MMF app. If the phone currently does not have a data connection, the workout will be saved locally to the phone and the MMF app will try to upload it later. This method will check if the app is connected. If it is not it will throw a RemoteException with RemoteException.Code.APP_NOT_CONNECTED

Throws:
RemoteException - if app is not connected.

startWithoutGpsCommand

public void startWithoutGpsCommand()
                            throws RemoteException
Tell the MMF app to start a workout, whether or not a GPS fix is available. This method will check if the app is connected. If it is not it will throw a RemoteException with RemoteException.Code.APP_NOT_CONNECTED

Throws:
RemoteException - if app is not connected.

cancelWorkoutStart

public void cancelWorkoutStart()
                        throws RemoteException
Tell the MMF app to cancel a workout start. This may happen if there was no GPS and the app is waiting for the user to confirm that he wants to start the workout withou it . This method will check if the app is connected. If it is not it will throw a RemoteException with RemoteException.Code.APP_NOT_CONNECTED

Throws:
RemoteException - if app is not connected.

requestAppState

public void requestAppState()
This method is a bit dangerous and it makes some assumptions. Ideally, if we are connected to an MMF app we would just ask it for the app state and get that state in the RemoteCommandListener.onAppStateEvent(AppState) callback. However, if we are not connected to an MMF app we can't be 100% sure which MMF app you intend to check for if the AppPackage is not set in this class. Lastly, if no RemoteCommandListener is set, you will not receieve a callback. In that case the method will appear to fail silently. These are steps we take:
  1. If MMF app is connected to SDK: ask it the current state and listen for it in the RemoteCommandListener.onAppStateEvent(AppState) callback. Remember if no callback is set, you will not get any feedback about the state of the app.
  2. If we have an AppPackage set, then check it to see if app is installed. If the app is installed we will send a callback with AppState.APP_NOT_CONNECTED. If the app is not installed we will send a callback with AppState.APP_NOT_INSTALLED.
  3. If the AppPackage is not set, we are not sure which one of the 10 apps you are requesting. In that case, we will use findInstalledApps() to see if any of our supported apps are installed. If at least one of them is installed we return AppState.APP_NOT_CONNECTED. If none of our supported are installed, we return AppState.APP_NOT_INSTALLED.
A better way to get an app's state is to use requestAppState(AppPackage) passing it the AppPackage you are interested in. That will be more precise by narrowing down the options to one app.

requestAppState

public void requestAppState(AppPackage appPackage)
This method tries to check the state of an app represented by an AppPackage. Remember, like requestAppState(), it no RemoteCommandListener is set, you will not receive any callbacks on the state of the app. These are the steps taken in this method:
  1. If the app is connected, we check if the AppPackage in the parameter is equal to the one set in this class. In that case, we ask the MMF app to send us the state. If the package in the parameter is different than the one held by this page, we check to see if it is installed or just not connected.
  2. If the app is not connected, we check if the package is installed, if so, we return AppState.APP_NOT_CONNECTED
  3. If none of the above qualify, we return AppState.APP_NOT_INSTALLED
You can also use the getAppInfo(AppPackage) method and the returned AppInfo object to see if the app is installed or not.

Parameters:
appPackage -

isAppConnected

public boolean isAppConnected()
Check if app is currently connected to one of the MMF apps. You can then use getAppPackage() to check which app it is.

Returns:
whether this is bound to an MMF's app service

findInstalledApps

public java.util.ArrayList<AppInfo> findInstalledApps()
Get a list of all MMF apps installed. This will return an empty AppInfo > object. Then you would know non of our supported apps are installed in the phone.

Returns:
array of type AppInfo with info on apps installed

appPackage - the app package which you want to check
Returns:
and AppInfo with info on the app
